clinical_study.brief_title: C-Reactive Protein as a Predictor of Stem Cell Transplant Complications
clinical_study.official_title: C-Reactive Protein As a Predictor of Major Transplant Complications in Pediatric Stem Cell Transplant Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

clinical_study.source: Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine if C-Reactive Protein levels are predictive for complications post transplant.

primary_outcome.measure: To determine whether quantitative c-reactive protein measurements can predict major morbidity and mortality in pediatric stem cell transplant patients.

intervention.description: Each patient enrolled in the study will have a serum quantitative c-reactive protein (crp) level drawn on the day of transplant, day 7 of transplant, and twice weekly after that until recovery of neutrophil count (approximately 20-25 days). Patients will be followed for 100 days post-transplant for the development of the following complications: Sepsis- defined as fever, positive blood culture, need for fluid resuscitation and/or pressor support. Acute GVHD > grade II defined according to the Seattle criteria VOD- defined according to the modified Seattle criteria

study_pop.textblock: Children undergoing a stem cell transplant

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 6 months to 20 years
- Patient undergoing a stem cell transplant (allogeneic, syngeneic, or autologous) at Childrens' Memorial Hospital
- IRB approved informed consent (and assent for children age 12-17)
